author: By Eric A. Taub
title: This Car’s Yearly Tune-Up Costs as Much as a Civic
description: The Bugatti Chiron commands a fortune, but for serious car aficionados in the 1 percent, it represents perfection. Perfection that can top out at 261 miles an hour.
content: I’ve never piloted the Concorde; but in early March, just before the coronavirus-fueled lockdown, I drove what may be the closest road equivalent to a luxury aircraft: the Bugatti Chiron.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, May 25, 2020.
content: The full-page presentation on Sunday that listed the names of people whose lives were lost to the coronavirus pandemic included several errors. The list erroneously included Jordan Driver Haynes. Mr. Haynes did not die of virus-related causes; his memorial service was delayed because of the outbreak. The following names were also erroneously included because of a misreading of local obituaries: John A. Rocco, Fannie Mae Person, Richard Wayne Cannon, Dorothea Elaine Young-Lane, Stephen Wald Levine, Robert L. Scarpino Jr., Elmer J. David and Jagdish C. Agarwal. The listing also omitted the surname of a professor at Gloucester County College. He was Henry Burk Sullivan, not Burk. It also omitted the surname of a master jeweler from Alpine, N.J. He was Fritz Wilhelm Reisgies, not Wilhelm. It misspelled the surname of a woman from Brookville, N.Y., who died on April 13. She was Joan M. Heaney, not Heany. The list also misstated Randall Clayton French’s age. He was 39, not 29.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Felix Schmitt and Tom Jamieson
title: As Passengers Disappeared, Airlines Filled Planes With Cargo
description: To make up for lost revenue during the pandemic, Lufthansa, Virgin Atlantic and other airlines are hauling more cargo on aircraft, including where passengers used to sit.
content: Most passenger planes today fly virtually empty, but when Virgin Atlantic flight VS251 landed at Heathrow Airport near London on a cloudy afternoon late last month, most of its 258 seats were occupied.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Virus at Its Deadliest in the Strongholds of Democrats
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 25, 2020.
content: “I guess other people expect us to set our futures on fire to keep their fear warm. I think that’s incredibly selfish — if you’re that fearful, then just stay home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Future Lands a Seventh No. 1 Album
description: “High Off Life” debuted at the top of the Billboard chart with the equivalent of 153,000 sales in the United States.
content: Hip-hop dominates the Billboard album chart once again, as Future reaches No. 1 with “High Off Life,” the seventh time in the last three months a rap album has held the top spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Letícia Casado and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: U.S. Bans Flights From Brazil, Where Pandemic Is Raging
description: Brazil’s leader, a coronavirus skeptic, has mocked public health measures. Now, with deaths skyrocketing, his ally President Trump has closed the door.
content: BRASÍLIA — The United States, citing Brazil’s surging coronavirus crisis, has banned flights from the nation, delivering a blow to its embattled leader, who has tried to use his warm relations with President Trump to bolster his political standing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: All Alone in a Three-Bedroom Apartment
description: When her roommates moved out during the coronavirus lockdown, a Brooklynite negotiated with her landlord and is making the best of the situation.
content: Bonnie Blue Edwards had long fantasized about taking over her three-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where she has spent 10 years living with roommates. But when both of her roommates moved out in March — one departure was planned, the other wasn’t — it was far from a dream scenario.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The New Model Media Star Is Famous Only to You
description: With short videos and paid newsletters, everyone from superstars to half-forgotten former athletes and even journalists can, as one tech figure put it, “monetize individuality.”
content: Back in March, I was trying to persuade my dad to stop taking the subway to work in Manhattan and join me upstate. So I paid $75 to Leonard Marshall, a retired New York Giants defensive lineman we both loved in the 1980s, to send the message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: In Memphis, Journalism Can Still Bring Justice
description: The nonprofit newsroom MLK50, founded by Wendi C. Thomas, aims to carry on the work that Martin Luther King Jr. started.
content: NASHVILLE — Wendi C. Thomas launched MLK50 in 2017 as a one-year project to make the 50th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a time to consider the current state of economic justice in the city where he was murdered while advocating for a living wage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Donald Trump, Joe Biden and the Vote of the Irish
description: From Tammany Hall to ‘Build the Wall,’ the long journey of Irish-American politics.
content: In 2016, my vantage point on the donnybrook between Donald and Hillary was an Irish bar in Queens, where I was a bartender a few nights a week. It was a cash-only joint that sometimes stayed open until 7 a.m. and sold discounted cigarettes driven up from Virginia, the sort of place where you could make $800 under the table but you also might get a bottle or a chair thrown at you. This was where I watched the presidential debates and noticed something interesting. Half the patrons were Irish immigrants who considered Mr. Trump a real “eejit,” but the other half, the Irish Americans, thought he was just grand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Héctor Tobar
title: Is the Age of the Road Trip Over Forever?
description: Hitchhiking, “bumming” and cross-country drives used to be safe and make us feel cool.
content: LOS ANGELES — In the age when it was coolest to be an American, we took to the roads, the seas and the air. We saw the country and the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Yuko
title: Business Casual? It’s Robes and Slippers All Day Now
description: Nonessential workers are embracing leisure wear, saying it makes them feel not just relaxed but powerful.
content: When Dr. Denise McDermott, 49, isn’t seeing patients for telehealth appointments, there’s a good chance she’s wearing a robe. In fact, as soon as she and her 11-year-old son finish the video portion of their work and school days, they both make the switch. “It’s become our joke during the pandemic: We’re the robe family,” said Dr. McDermott, a psychiatrist in Manhattan Beach, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Yorkers Mark a Subdued Memorial Day
description: Governor Cuomo, on the deck of the U.S.S. Intrepid, said the state would pay benefits to the families of workers who died while fighting the virus.
content: Memorial Day weekend serves as a peek into what the city will look like in the coming months, a taste of summer that keeps New Yorkers looking forward.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As the U.S. Honors Memorial Day, Trump Threatens to Move Republican Convention
description: The president threatened to yank the Republican National Convention from Charlotte, N.C. Meatpacking plants are reopening, but data about how many workers are ill is elusive.
content: This briefing has ended. Read live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Remains of 60 Mammoths Found in Mexico
description: Archaeologists said the remains found near the site of a former lake could suggest the animals were hunted after they got stuck in mud.
content: Archaeologists in Mexico have discovered the remains of dozens of mammoths in a finding that could shed further light on the hunting methods of prehistoric communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Sarah Kliff
title: Wealthiest Hospitals Got Billions in Bailout for Struggling Health Providers
description: Twenty large chains received more than $5 billion in federal grants even while sitting on more than $100 billion in cash.
content: A multibillion-dollar institution in the Seattle area invests in hedge funds, runs a pair of venture capital funds and works with elite private equity firms like the Carlyle Group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: He Thought He Was Getting Football Physicals. He Was Being Abused.
description: Chuck Christian played on some of Michigan’s best teams. More than 40 years later, he sees a connection between a university doctor’s assaults and a dire prognosis.
content: For more than 40 years, Chuck Christian did not call himself a victim because he did not think he was one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Dirt,’ Bill Buford Goes in Search of French Cuisine’s Secrets
description: Buford recounts his intensely focused experiences in restaurant kitchens after moving his family to Lyon.
content: Bill Buford has had a storied and variegated career, a mix of high and low and sensitive and almost macho — a career that has twisted gently, like a flamed citrus peel destined for a Negroni.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: My Mother Died of the Coronavirus. It’s Time She Be Counted.
description: Not having an accurate, honest, nationwide way to tally Covid-19 cases will only add to the current tragedy.
content: We recently received the death certificate for my mother, who died May 4 in an assisted-living facility near New York City. “Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome” was the primary cause. And the secondary — no surprise — was “suspected Covid-19.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: In Praise of Fallible Leaders
description: We need a president who can admit it when he’s wrong.
content: Last week Joe Biden made an off-the-cuff joke that could be interpreted as taking African-American votes for granted. It wasn’t a big deal — Biden, who loyally served Barack Obama, has long had a strong affinity with black voters, and he has made a point of issuing policy proposals aimed at narrowing racial health and wealth gaps. Still, Biden apologized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Herschthal
title: How to Save Sleepaway Camps
description: A plan to transform camps into safe retreats for families.
content: Imagine this: Just over the horizon, deep purple and orange skies, the sun setting behind emerald-green mountains. You and your partner are sitting close together, listening to the campfire musicians, while your children roast s’mores in the distance. You’re not even paying that much attention to them now — that’s what the summer camp counselors are for. Instead you’re sharing a laugh, about how terrible you were at rock climbing earlier that day. Those are exactly the kinds of restorative moments a family retreat at summer camp can provide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Lufthansa to Receive $10 Billion Bailout
description: The German government, which will take a 20 percent stake in the airline, said Lufthansa was facing an ‘existential emergency.’
content: Lufthansa will receive a bailout worth 9 billion euros, or $9.8 billion, to help the airline survive an “existential emergency” caused by the pandemic and a virtual shutdown of passenger air traffic, the German government said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Coronavirus Threatens China’s Devotion to Chopsticks and Sharing Food
description: Faced with the spread of the coronavirus, the government is promoting using serving utensils, but resistance is strong. Sharing food with personal chopsticks is one way Chinese people express intimacy.
content: At Chilli Kitchen in Beijing, spicy and mouth-numbing Sichuan dishes are laid out family style. Using red chopsticks, diners dive into steaming bowls of pork wontons bathed in fragrant chili oil and sesame seeds, and rummage through platters filled with dried red chili peppers to unearth juicy bits of roasted fish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: National Hockey League Edges Toward Restart With Detailed Plans
description: A modified playoff format, restricted practices and other considerations are being discussed between league executives and the players’ union.
content: A game once played outdoors in subzero temperatures and wool sweaters may soon crown its champion during the swelter of summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 5, Episode 4: Hometown Hero
description: Bobby goes home to Yonkers to build support for a major development project. But did he ever really leave?
content: Wendy Rhoades stares at the man opposite her. And stares. And stares. And stares some more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melanie Pinola
title: The 7 Things You Need for an Ergonomic Workstation
description: If you’re working from home indefinitely, it may be time to upgrade that home office.
content: After years of slumping at a desk, I’ve begun to suffer the aches that come from having a poor work-space setup. The stiff chair, the desk that’s too tall and the cramped laptop keyboard have all become literal pains in the neck (and shoulders and back and elsewhere). If your home-office setup is less than ideal, it may be time to upgrade the space ergonomically, especially now that most nonessential businesses plan to keep employees working from home indefinitely.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.25 Million in California
description: A one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco, a renovated midcentury house in Redondo Beach and a 1940 farmhouse in Sebastopol.
content: A one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco, a renovated midcentury house in Redondo Beach and a 1940 farmhouse in Sebastopol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Pass the Popcorn and Shhh! The Wedding Is About to Start
description: Two brides, Lindsey Leaverton and Bri Houk, shared their happy ending (or is it a beginning?) on the big screens at Doc’s Drive-In Theatre in Buda, Texas.
content: On what was supposed to be their wedding night, Lindsey Leaverton and Bri Houk sat in their car on the top floor of a parking garage in North Austin and ate pizza, watched the sunset and finished off a Yeti full of champagne. “I put on a private concert for Bri and we danced under the stars,” Ms. Leaverton said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Which Party Would Benefit Most From Voting by Mail? It’s Complicated
description: Conventional wisdom has been that Democrats are more likely to benefit from voting by mail. But that’s not what research has shown.
content: WASHINGTON — Not so many months ago, casting a ballot by mail was a topic reserved for conferences of election administrators, a matter of voting mechanics blander than a water cracker. In Republican Arizona and Democratic Oregon as well as many other states, vast numbers of citizens not only voted by mail, but also loved it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Robert Gebeloff
title: The Coronavirus Is Deadliest Where Democrats Live
description: Beyond perception and ideology, there are starkly different realities for red and blue America right now.
content: The staggering American death toll from the coronavirus, now approaching 100,000, has touched every part of the country, but the losses have been especially acute along its coasts, in its major cities, across the industrial Midwest, and in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Murphy Schlichting and Adrian Benepe
title: New York City Doesn’t Have to Suffer This Summer
description: Officials shouldn’t let the coronavirus end a long history of helping people stay cool.
content: New Yorkers are entering the summer season with no access to the traditional cooling infrastructure — the cold water found in playground sprinklers, public pools, and beaches — which Mayor Bill de Blasio has declared off-limits because of concerns about the coronavirus and the budget. Millions of residents will find themselves on an unpleasant — and potentially deadly — trip back in time to the turn of the 20th century, when summers were always “too darn hot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: He Placed in a Virtual Race. But His Racing Was Too Virtual.
description: A driver in a virtual Formula E race apologized for “outside help” in placing third.
content: Daniel Abt might be a successful driver on the Formula E circuit, the racecar series normally using electric cars, but he had not been so good at the virtual races that are substituting for the real thing during the coronavirus pandemic. In the first four races, he had failed to score a point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: By Air and Sea, Mercenaries Landed in Libya. Then the Plan Went South.
description: A short-lived mission uncovered by U.N. investigators offers a glimpse into the world of those who have thrived off Libya’s chaos.
content: CAIRO — Two former British marines piloted their boats, a pair of military-grade inflatables, across the Mediterranean from Malta. Six helicopters were flown in from Botswana using falsified papers. The rest of the team — soldiers of fortune from South Africa, Britain, Australia and the United States — arrived from a staging area in Jordan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: ISIS Prisoners Threaten U.S. Mission in Northeastern Syria
description: Overcrowded, makeshift prisons and camps and fears of Covid-19 have led to two riots by hardened fighters.
content: WASHINGTON — A year after American-backed forces seized the last remnant of territory under Islamic State rule in Syria, some 10,000 captured ISIS fighters in Kurdish-run wartime prisons pose “a significant risk” to the United States mission in the country’s northeast, military commanders say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: New Zealand Earthquake Interrupts Jacinda Ardern’s TV Interview
description: When the rattling from the magnitude-5.8 quake stopped, New Zealand’s prime minister continued the interview, seeming unruffled.
content: A sizable earthquake struck New Zealand on Monday, shaking Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern during a live television interview, but failing to cause major damage or disrupt Ms. Ardern’s calm demeanor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When ‘Mrs.’ Became an Uncomfortable Fit
description: Women share their stories of change and self-affirmation.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Japan, Sydney’s schools, New Zealand quake: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Restrictions on Tokyo and the northern island of Hokkaido were lifted on Monday, ending the last measures that were put in place. Japan entered a new phase of its pandemic response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hans Taparia
title: The Future of College Is Online, and It’s Cheaper
description: The coronavirus forced a shift to virtual classes, but their continuation could be beneficial even after the pandemic ends.
content: Forty years ago, going to college in America was a reliable pathway for upward mobility. Today, it has become yet another 21st-century symbol of privilege for the wealthy. Through this period, tuition rates soared 260 percent, double the rate of inflation. In 2019, the average cost of attending a four-year private college was over $200,000. For a four-year public college, it was over $100,000. To sustain these prices, more students are now admitted from the top 1 percent of the income scale than the entire bottom 40 percent at the top 80 colleges. Universities have also opened the floodgates to wealthy international students, willing to pay full tuition for the American brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: For Kenny Chesney and Others, Promotion in a Pandemic Is a Quandary
description: How do you ask for attention when the world is consumed by a life-or-death crisis?
content: Kenny Chesney was supposed to take the stage last month in his signature straw hat and weathered boots at the AT&T Stadium in Dallas. The event was designed to help kick off an album, “Here And Now,” on which he had worked for about three years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Keeping Bookstores Safe
description: A reader suggest that they hand out disposable gloves to browsing customers. Also: Retaliatory dismissals.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Air Force Removes Height Requirement to Attract More Women Pilots
description: The Air Force said it was dispensing with a restriction that effectively eliminated about 44 percent of American women between the ages of 20 and 29.
content: The Air Force has removed its minimum height requirement for prospective pilots in a move that it said would encourage a more diverse pool of applicants, particularly women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: On a Scottish Isle, Nursing Home Deaths Expose a Covid-19 Scandal
description: At the Home Farm nursing home on the Isle of Skye, more than a quarter of its residents died and nearly all were infected with coronavirus. Families are furious.
content: On the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, residents thought they had sealed themselves off from the coronavirus. They shuttered hotels. Officials warned of police checks. Traffic emptied on the only bridge from the mainland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: It’s the Year 2120. MasterClass Is the Only School Left.
description: People love success. But can they learn it?
content: In mid-March, as much of the world withdrew into their homes, the celebrity-powered e-learning platform MasterClass began to notice that people who encountered its advertisements were often watching them in full.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Paradox of Memorial Day
description: Take time to think about those we’ve lost, then cook for those nearest to you.
content: Good morning. One hundred and one years ago, the American ambassador to France, Hugh Wallace, invited President Woodrow Wilson to speak at a Memorial Day ceremony near Paris, to honor American doughboys killed during World War I. The president had been in France for months attending to the peace process and was in ill health, a victim of the flu epidemic that had begun to roil the world the previous year. Still, he rallied:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Tiger vs. Phil (and Tom vs. Peyton) Turn Rivalry Into Laughs
description: Tiger Woods beat Phil Mickelson in a head-to-head rematch while their mortal-looking N.F.L. partners — Tom Brady and Peyton Manning — drew barbs and laughs.
content: The charity golf match pitting Tiger Woods and Peyton Manning against Phil Mickelson and Tom Brady on Sunday figured to be good TV. It had big names, longstanding rivalries spanning two sports, an intriguing combination of talents and the prospect of the unforeseen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Hannah Gadsby on Comedy Trolls, Anti-Vaxxers and Burying Her Dog
description: ‘People who want to hate me — there’s nothing I can do about it.’
content: ‘People who want to hate me — there’s nothing I can do about it.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: Couples Who Eat Together May Not Stay Together
description: From what they eat to how they actually eat it, being together all the time is only intensifying food issues.
content: Since the global pandemic lockdown began, Marianne Andrews, Jonathan Miller and their two teenagers have been eating dinner together every night, and sometimes lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Chairing a Gala While Stuck in Mustique
description: How Adrienne Arsht, Tonya Lewis Lee and Dee Ocleppo Hilfiger are hunkering down.
content: With the New York gala scene on hiatus, here is how some patrons and society figures are spending their time and resources during the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Hong Kong, Dominic Cummings, New Zealand: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Biden Can Beat Trump … if He Doesn’t Blow It
description: Joe being stuck at home during an election year may turn out to be a good thing.
content: As the United States’ death toll raced toward 100,000, Donald Trump went golfing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: Richard Anuszkiewicz, Whose Op Art Caught Eyes in the ’60s, Dies at 89
description: He was a pioneer in manipulating fundamental elements of art to create optical effects — and to make, as he put it, “something romantic out of a very, very mechanistic geometry.”
content: Richard Anuszkiewicz, a pioneering practitioner of Op Art in the United States before that perception-altering style was even given a name in the 1960s, died on May 19 at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelsey Baker
title: He Died at War. The Pandemic Gave Me Time to Grieve.
description: My partner, Diego Pongo, was killed in Iraq in March. More than two months later, the pandemic has paused everything, including his funeral.
content: When I met Diego D. Pongo at the gym, neither of us was looking for a relationship. I was preparing to deploy to Iraq for just over six months, and he was more focused on being a good parent to his young daughter than on dating. He was a Marine Raider with U.S. Marine Special Operations Command out of Camp Lejeune in North Carolina. I offered him a ride back to his work, though it was only a two-minute walk from the gym. He agreed, and gave me his number as he got out of my car. I put it in my phone as “Handsome Diego.” On one of our first dates, we took a long walk through the marshes surrounding North Topsail Beach, on the North Carolina coast. While the tide was out, we walked out to a small island a couple hundred feet from the shore. I wondered if I had foolishly fallen too hard for him right before a deployment. We had agreed that this wouldn’t become anything serious. Neither of us noticed the rising tide that would soon leave us stranded. He held my shoes and clothes over his head and led the way as we waded through the cold water, cutting our feet on slivers of shells while we scrambled back to the beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doris Salcedo
title: Naming the Disappeared, Raising the Dead
description: Art can give witness to those who governments have tried to erase from history.
content: This essay is part of The Big Ideas, a special section of The Times’s philosophy series, The Stone, in which more than a dozen artists, writers and thinkers answer the question, “Why does art matter?” The entire series can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Firshein
title: Help! One Company Refused to Refund Travelers More Than $100,000
description: Then our columnist intervened with the Boston-based tour operator Overseas Adventure Travel.
content: My trip to Egypt with Overseas Adventure Travel was scheduled to depart in late March. O.A.T. canceled the tour because of Covid-19, which was a relief. The company notified me of the cancellation and offered either a credit for rebooking or a full refund that would have included airfare. The next week, I learned via email that I had been rebooked on the same trip next year. Unbeknown to me, the stated policy had changed: O.A.T. was no longer offering refunds. I told them that I had a medical condition and did not know when — or if — I would be able to travel, and asked whether they were just going to keep my $17,500 if I couldn’t travel by the end of 2021. Answer: Yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Strings
title: It’s Not Obesity. It’s Slavery.
description: We know why Covid-19 is killing so many black people.
content: About five years ago, I was invited to sit in on a meeting about health in the African-American community. Several important figures in the fields of public health and economics were present. A freshly minted Ph.D., I felt strangely like an interloper. I was also the only black person in the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Putin Speaks, Officials Shrug, and Doctors Are Caught in the Middle
description: A botched effort to reward people keeping the coronavirus in check leaves doctors and nurses who demand their due facing scrutiny.
content: MOSCOW — Assailed by critics as an absentee leader at the start of the coronavirus crisis in Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin re-emerged with a splash on state television last month to show that he cared and was taking charge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Burundi’s Ruling Party Candidate Wins Presidency
description: The election was marred by accusations from the leading opposition challenger of vote rigging.
content: NAIROBI — Burundi’s ruling party candidate, a retired general, has won the presidential election, the country’s electoral commission said on Monday amid accusations of vote-rigging by the leading opposition challenger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain’s Courts, Already Strained, Face Crisis as Lockdown Lifts
description: A country known for litigiousness has gingerly restarted court proceedings, and lawyers are bracing for chaos.
content: MADRID — A flood of new court cases, some with little precedent, is expected to deluge a Spanish judicial system already gasping for breath, bogged down by delays and lagging in technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: New Yorkers Embark on a Summer of Uncertainty
description: Memorial Day weekend in New York City usually marks the beginning of a vibrant summer to come. But this year traditions have been altered under the shadow of the coronavirus.
content: Memorial Day weekend in New York City usually marks the beginning of a vibrant summer to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Hoping for a Covid Vaccine and Recalling the One for Smallpox
description: It’s worth reflecting on the biologic brilliance of the technique and on what our bodies and immune systems are capable of doing, when appropriately prompted.
content: As many people check the news compulsively for even the smallest positive word on vaccine development, we are at an anniversary moment in vaccine history. We are between the anniversary of the day — May 14, 1796 — that Edward Jenner inoculated 8-year-old James Phipps with cowpox virus, and the day — July 1, 1796 — that he tested his new process by inoculating the same child with smallpox virus, to find out whether he was protected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Hafner
title: Fear of Covid Leads Other Patients to Decline Critical Treatment
description: Psychologists say anxiety and uncertainty prompt irrational decisions — like turning down a transplant when an organ becomes available.
content: It was the call Lance Hansen, gravely ill with liver disease, had been waiting weeks for, and it came just before midnight in late April. A liver was available for him. He got up to get dressed for the three-hour drive to San Francisco for the transplant surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Hoping for a Covid Vaccine and Recalling the One for Smallpox
description: It’s worth reflecting on the biologic brilliance of the technique and on what our bodies and immune systems are capable of doing, when appropriately prompted.
content: As many people check the news compulsively for even the smallest positive word on vaccine development, we are at an anniversary moment in vaccine history. We are between the anniversary of the day — May 14, 1796 — that Edward Jenner inoculated 8-year-old James Phipps with cowpox virus, and the day — July 1, 1796 — that he tested his new process by inoculating the same child with smallpox virus, to find out whether he was protected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wilkinson
title: The Brutal Clarity of the Trump-McConnell Plan to Protect Businesses
description: The liability-protection ruse is an excuse to coerce Americans back to work by refusing desperately needed help.
content: House Democrats have passed a new “phase four” $3 trillion coronavirus relief bill. You could call it an opening bid toward a package to support a sensible, deliberate economic reopening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Catie Edmondson
title: ‘This Is Not the Hunger Games’: National Testing Strategy Draws Concerns
description: The Trump administration’s report to Congress sees states taking responsibility for coronavirus testing with federal guidance.
content: The Trump administration’s new testing strategy, released Sunday to Congress, holds individual states responsible for planning and carrying out all coronavirus testing, while planning to provide some supplies needed for the tests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: Dominic Cummings Offers a Sorry-Not-Sorry for U.K. Lockdown Breach
description: The top adviser to Prime Minister Boris Johnson caused a furor after it was learned he had driven 260 miles to his parents’ home.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson took a breathtaking gamble with his own popularity on Monday, allowing his closest aide to go public with a detailed, yet stubbornly unapologetic, explanation for making a 260-mile journey that broke lockdown rules and ignited a political firestorm in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerry Garrett
title: James Bond’s Car Comes to Life With Oil-Slick Sprayer, but No Ejector Seat
description: Aston Martin is re-creating the Bond DB5, as seen in “Goldfinger,” with all the (responsible) spy gear it could stuff into it.
content: James Bond is lonely. It’s just 007 and his gadget-laden 1965 Aston Martin DB5 these days. He hasn’t had any company since his last passenger was ejected. His car phone can’t call anyone; for one thing, its inventor didn’t remember to include a dial. His radar-mapping system is frozen on some place in rural Sussex, and just emits beeps like a sonar signal from a submarine movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Virgin Orbit Launch Attempt Ends Without Trip to Space
description: The company, founded by Richard Branson, had hoped to show that it can send small satellites to orbit from virtually anywhere.
content: Strap a rocket to the underside of a plane. Fly it up several miles. Drop it. The engine ignites, and the rocket and its payload zoom to space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Threatens to Pull Republican National Convention From North Carolina
description: The president, who has wondered aloud to aides why the convention can’t be held in Florida, said North Carolina’s governor needed to “guarantee” that the event could be held in August.
content: President Trump on Monday threatened to yank the Republican National Convention from Charlotte, N.C., where it is scheduled to be held in August, accusing the state’s Democratic governor of being in a “shutdown mood” that could prevent a fully attended event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Andrea Salcedo
title: UConn Student Went on Rampage, Killing 2 Before Fleeing, Police Say
description: Authorities are seeking Peter Manfredonia, 23, who was last seen in the Poconos of Pennsylvania.
content: On Friday morning, Ted DeMers was driving down a leafy street he knew well, in a rural town in northeast Connecticut, when he spotted a young man on foot wearing a motorcycle helmet. Mr. DeMers stopped to speak to him and the man climbed into his vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Cost of Rushing Back to Sports: A Star’s Life
description: The 1919 Stanley Cup finals were more than a century ago, but they are bound to current reality by the struggle against a deadly virus and the push for sports to return.
content: Nobody made much of it when Joe Hall skated off the ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Cost of Rushing Back to Sports: A Star’s Life
description: The 1919 Stanley Cup finals were more than a century ago, but they are bound to current reality by the struggle against a deadly virus and the push for sports to return.
content: Nobody made much of it when Joe Hall skated off the ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Join Us for a Look at a Century of Progress for Women
description: Times journalists and guests will discuss 100 years of change and the barriers that remain. Plus, balancing parenthood with alone time, the future of bookstores and more live events this week.
content: The coronavirus has transformed nearly every aspect of daily life, but Times journalists are here to keep you informed and connected from home. Below is a selection of our live events this week (all times are Eastern). You can find the full calendar here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bari Weiss
title: Joe Rogan Is the New Mainstream Media
description: Talking to the podcasting king about his monster Spotify deal.
content: When I saw the news that the king of all podcasting, Joe Rogan, had inked a deal with Spotify for his widely popular show I texted to congratulate him on getting crazy rich. How rich?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Gucci Says Fashion Shows Should Never Be the Same
description: The Italian brand is reducing its runway schedule. Your Instagram is about to change.
content: Gucci wants to change show business. Or, rather, the business of shows. The Italian brand has joined the chorus of brands and retailers calling for a permanent reset of the fashion system thanks to Covid-19, adding the weight of a giant global name to the movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.25 Million Homes in California
description: A one-bedroom condominium in San Francisco, a renovated midcentury house in Redondo Beach and a 1940 farmhouse in Sebastopol.
content: The Redstone, a 24-unit condominium in the Russian Hill neighborhood, was designed by Henry Clay Smith, an early 20th-century architect known for his skill at building large structures on San Francisco’s hilly terrain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcella Goheen
title: The Crisis at My Husband’s Nursing Home
description: The loss of 98 lives there is nothing short of a tragedy.
content: For the last three and a half years, my husband has lived at the Isabella Geriatric Center, a two-tower high-rise nursing home in the heart of Washington Heights. In a period of six weeks, as many as 98 people living there died from Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: African-Americans Are Highly Visible in the Military, but Almost Invisible at the Top
description: Seventy-five years after integration, the military’s upper echelons remain the domain of white men.
content: WASHINGTON — A photograph of President Trump and his top four-star generals and admirals, tweeted in October by Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper, was meant as a thank-you to the commander in chief. But it angered a lot of others, and not just those who erupted on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: A 96-Year-Old Veteran Was Near Death. Then He Met His Social Worker.
description: After Covid-19 killed his wife, George Crouch had little spirit to fight his own battle against the disease. But he found common ground with a military visitor.
content: The outlook for the patient assigned to Capt. Eric Dungan on May 1 was bleak: George Crouch, 96, seemed to have given up on life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu
title: How Will We Remember the Pandemic? Museums Are Already Deciding
description: Wanted: Artifacts that show how Americans navigated the Covid-19 crisis. The trick is determining what’s historically valuable.
content: LOS ANGELES — Six-year-old Franklin Wong captured the simple frustration of being a student in this city’s Unified School District in mid-March, after his classes were canceled. He wrote in big blocky letters: “I did not go anywhere,” and added an unhappy face in green and red crayon for his remote-learning assignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: To Fight Covid-19, Don’t Neglect Immunity and Inflammation
description: After seeing who is most likely to become infected and die, immunity and inflammation warrant further discussion and public attention.
content: While most people focus, as they should, on social distancing, face coverings, hand washing and even self-isolation to protect against the deadly coronavirus now ravaging the country, too few are paying serious attention to two other factors critically important to the risk of developing a Covid-19 infection and its potential severity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Maggie Haberman
title: Joe Biden, Wearing Mask, Appears in Public at a Veterans Memorial
description: The presumptive Democratic nominee made a public appearance for the first time since mid-March, cutting a contrast with President Trump, who did not wear a mask at two Memorial Day events.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has been campaigning from his home for more than two months during the coronavirus crisis, on Monday made his first public appearance since mid-March, visiting a veterans memorial in Delaware.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany and Derek Kravitz
title: As Meatpacking Plants Reopen, Data About Worker Illness Remains Elusive
description: Emails show local officials received conflicting signals from state leaders and meatpacking companies about how much information to release about outbreaks in plants.
content: The Smithfield Foods plant in Tar Heel, N.C., is one of the world’s largest pork processing facilities, employing about 4,500 people and slaughtering roughly 30,000 pigs a day at its peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: To Fight Covid-19, Don’t Neglect Immunity and Inflammation
description: After seeing who is most likely to become infected and die, immunity and inflammation warrant further discussion and public attention.
content: While most people focus, as they should, on social distancing, face coverings, hand washing and even self-isolation to protect against the deadly coronavirus now ravaging the country, too few are paying serious attention to two other factors critically important to the risk of developing a Covid-19 infection and its potential severity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Popescu
title: How Will We Remember the Pandemic? Museums Are Already Deciding
description: Wanted: Artifacts that show how Americans navigated the Covid-19 crisis. The trick is determining what’s historically valuable.
content: LOS ANGELES — Six-year-old Franklin Wong captured the simple frustration of being a student in this city’s Unified School District in mid-March, after his classes were canceled. He wrote in big blocky letters: “I did not go anywhere,” and added an unhappy face in green and red crayon for his remote-learning assignment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Amy Schumer Misses Stand-Up. (‘I Should Have Said My Dad, but That’s Not the Truth.’)
description: Because of coronavirus concerns, she expects it will be at least a year before she returns to Comedy Cellar: “You need masks with good acoustics.”
content: It didn’t take long for Amy Schumer to shut down her old life. “The first day I heard the term Wuhan market, that was it,” she said in a recent interview. “I was one of those people who was like: Pack your bags.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: How a Pianist Salvaged His Lost Carnegie Hall Debut
description: Once the coronavirus pandemic canceled concerts around the world, Timo Andres decided to reconstruct his recital as a series of YouTube videos.
content: It’s a story that has become tragically common since the coronavirus pandemic brought live performances to a halt: The composer and pianist Timo Andres spent months preparing for his Carnegie Hall recital debut this spring. Then the concert was canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Oil-Starved Venezuela Celebrates Arrival of Tankers From Iran
description: The shipment represents a deepening of ties between two pariah states that are both under U.S. sanctions.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — An oil tanker called “Fortune” has sailed into Venezuela from Iran, the first of five ships expected to arrive in a nation so starved of gasoline that the docking of a single tanker was hailed on Monday by government officials as a victory.
source.name: The New York Times
